titlestmt.titleproper: Finding aid to the Carole De Saram papers SSC.MS.00794

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2018-11-26 15:23:51 -0500.

did.unittitle: Carole De Saram papers

physdesc.extent: (8 record cartons, 2 oversize boxes, 1 full document box, 2 half document boxes, and 1 flat file folder)
(76 files copied from one flash drive)

did.abstract: Carole De Saram was a feminist activist in the 1970s, working as President of New York City National Organization for Women (NOW) for women's equality in all fields. Her papers include documents, legal information, conference and protest information, and organizational information about the National Organization for Women, as well as photographs, correspondence, and personal documents of Carole De Saram.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for use without restriction beyond the standard terms and conditions of Smith College Special Collections.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Initial accession donated by Carole De Saram in December 2017; subsequent accessions were donated over the course of 2018

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Carole De Saram was a feminist activist in the 1970s, working as President of New York City National Organization for Women (NOW) for women's equality in all fields.

Born February 27, 1939 in Queens, New York, De Saram began her career in computing, working on Wall Street at the American Stock Exchange. Inspired by a Wall Street Journal article on women striking for equality, De Saram attended the 1970 March for Equality, and continued working for NOW from that day on. Among her achievements were the woman-led stock exchange takeover, the creation of a women's bank and the Feminist Credit Union, disruption of the US presentation at the 1975 International Women's Conference in Mexico City to protest their choice of US representatives, and numerous incendiary demonstrations against sexist practices of New York City businesses. She became President of NOW NY in 1974, serving two terms, and rose through the ranks at Chemical Bank to become Assistant Vice President while pioneering computer projects with IBM. Written about in "Glamour," investigated by the FBI, and still working in activism in the 2010s, Carole De Saram left her mark on the feminist movement as a whole.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: This collection contains materials received from the donor in digital form that are not currently available online. Please consult with Special Collections staff to request access to this digital content."

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Carole De Saram Papers, Sophia Smith Collection, MS 794, Smith College Special Collections, Northampton, Massachusetts.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Materials were sorted into similar categories, with original folders and order maintained when possible. Some subsequent accessions have been housed together. Open for use, with the caveat that this collection has not been processed, in the sense that archival arrangement and description beyond creating minimal box lists has not been done. The arrangement and description of materials may change in the future as iterative processing occurs. Researchers are encouraged to document their citations with this in mind.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Carole De Saram papers document her role agitating for credit for women in the 1970s and 1980s as part of NYC Now, as well as her participation in International Women's Year in Mexico City. The collection is largely clippings, although original records are interspersed throughout.

The collection includes documents, legal information (FOI requests and responses, lawsuit information, ERA legal proceedings), NOW national conference packets, and protest information, as well as organizational information (membership lists, board meeting notes and proceedings, various referenda) about the National Organization for Women. The collection also includes photographs, correspondence, digital photos and documents related to the Women's Movement compiled by Carole De Saram, and personal documents of Carole De Saram. Also included are videotapes, books, and newspapers relevant to International Women's Year and other feminist issues.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: To the extent that she owns copyright, Carole De Saram has licensed her materials to be freely used, so long as the user attributes materials' original authorship to her. This agreement is governed by a CC-BY (Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International) license. Copyright in other items in this collection may be held by their respective creators. For reproductions of materials that are governed by fair use as defined under U. S. Copyright Law, no permission to cite or publish is required. For instances which may regard materials in the collection not created by Carole De Saram, researchers are responsible for determining who may hold materials' copyrights and obtaining approval from them. Researchers do not need anything further from Smith College Special Collections to move forward with their use.

did.unittitle: Carole De Saram papers

physdesc.extent: (8 record cartons, 1 oversize box and 1 flat file folder)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes documents, legal information (FOI requests and responses, lawsuit information, ERA legal proceedings), NOW national conference packets, and protest information, as well as organizational information (membership lists, board meeting notes and proceedings, various referenda) about the National Organization for Women. Also includes photographs, correspondence, digital files on the "Women's Movement" compiled by Carole de Saram (2017), and personal documents of Carole De Saram.

did.unittitle: National NOW newspapers and newsletters, including "Do It Now!"
National NOW Equal Rights Amendment actions
National NOW Legal Defense & Education Fund
NOW regional conference records
NOW national conference records
National NOW "Zap" actions
National NOW Board records, including notes, correspondence, press releases, and member bios
National NOW board split and walk out
Politics and elections, including women's campaigns and the inauguration of Jimmy Carter

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes information on elections (both local and national) including the Jimmy Carter Presidential election and inauguration, information about women's participation in politics, NOW elections, NOW publications on which local or national politicans to endorse, and an NBC piece on the history of women's suffrage.

did.unittitle: Sex discrimination cases, including Congressional hearings, newspaper clippings, correspondence, and NOW Stockholder Action Task Force materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes research and evidence on various cases of gender discrimination, press articles, relevant New York State laws, a FOI request filed by de Saram and its responses, information from Congressional hearings on discrimination cases, and information on corporate stocks.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Various publications on women's rights and the women's movement, including those from NOW, women's history archives, legal guides and reports, and pamphlets.

dao.title: Link to File list for "Women's Movement" : presentation materials compiled electronically by Carole De Saram

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Primarily scanned photographs and documents. Topics include women's organizations (NOW, IWY), actions, and issues (ERA); conventions; letters, speaking engagements; and personal photographs.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: This file contains materials received from the donor in digital form that are not currently available online. Please consult with Special Collections staff to request access to this digital content.

did.unittitle: International Women's Year conference and Equal Rights Amendment posters
Carole De Saram papers addition

physdesc.extent: (2 record cartons and 1 large card file)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials include documents, membership lists, and correspondence, and news clippings pertaining to several feminist organizations, including the National Organization for Women, New York NOW, First Women's Bank, Redstockings, and Veteran Feminists of America. This accession also contains legal information, such as FOI requests and responses, class action lawsuit information and testimonials, and clippings about ERA legal proceedings. Information about other influential feminists and political races of the 1970s, photographs, and personal documents of Carole De Saram are also included.

"The Technology of Orgasm" Dell Williams video and accompanying Wendy Slick correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One video tape titled, "The Technology of Orgasm," accompanying card addressed to De Saram from Wendy Slick

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The video tape is of the Dell Williams clip shown at her tribute.

did.unittitle: Video recording, "The Technology of Orgasm," Dell Williams clip
Correspondence regarding "The Technology of Orgasm" from Wendy Slick
Carole De Saram books

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Books, some low print-run and some signed by the author, all collected by Carol De Saram. Books include Sexual Politics (inscribed by author), Sappho Was a Right-On Woman (inscribed by author), The Rights of Women: The Basic ACLU Guide to a Woman's Rights, Feminist Revolution Redstockings journal, "...To Form a More Perfect Union..." report of the National Commission on the Observance of International Women's Year, and Constitutional Aspects of the Right to Limit Childbearing report of the United States Commission on Civil Rights. Pamphlets include "Women's Resource Guide to NYC," published by NOW-New York City, and "About the NWHC," published by the National Women's Health Coalition.

did.unittitle: Carole De Saram collection of UN World Conference on Women Mexico City (1975) newspapers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Newspapers and periodicals collected by De Saram, related to the International Women's Year UN conference in Mexico City. Titles include El Heraldo de Mexico, El Universal, Excelsior, Novedades, and Xilonen, the daily newspaper of the International Women's Year Tribunal
